results.title: Growing up fast
results.creator_credit: John Croxford, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: It was itchy feet that encouraged John Croxford to join the Australian Navy. He spent most of his time patrolling the Korean coast where there was no room for mistakes.
results.creator_credit_for_label: John Croxford, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI

results.title: Wake up call
results.creator_credit: Jack Pearce, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: While Jack Pearce may have missed the war, there was still plenty of dangerous work for him to do, clearing mines up the Queensland coast for the Australian Navy.

results.title: Becoming an Australian
results.creator_credit: George Logan, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: It wasn’t until George Logan served in the army overseas that he felt like a true Australian. Serving as an infantryman in Malaya and Vietnam, it was the values of mateship, care and concern for others that remain with Logan today.
results.creator_credit_for_label: George Logan, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI

results.title: Always a survivor
results.creator_credit: David Catterall, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: When David Catterall returned from the horrors of the Vietnam War, he found his personal and professional life disintergrating. It was then that Catterall discovered the supportive community made up by his fellow returned soldiers and credits them with enabling him to pull through some of the darkest moments of his life.

results.title: Packages from home
results.creator_credit: Dave Piggott, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: When Dave Piggott went to fight in the Vietnam War at 19, it was a very different world to life back in Australia. With the help of the friends he made in the army, he soon got used to life there and it’s the funny stories and good friends that remain with him today.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Dave Piggott, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI

results.title: Reminiscing
results.creator_credit: Alf Thornton, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Alf Thornton fondly recalls his time serving in the Australian Navy during World War II, when letting your mates down was more feared than being killed. When Thornton returned, he spent most of his time trying to regain his lost youth but eventually found an anchor on the H.M.A.S. Castlemaine.

results.title: In our words: stories from Victorian veterans [November 2010]
results.brief_description: Nine Victorian war veterans tell of their experiences through the creation of digital stories, as part of ACMI’s Digital Storytelling workshop. While the horror and dangers and residual trauma of war are evident, these stories also pay tribute to the qualities of mateship and bravery instilled in them by the experience.

results.title: An Interview with Laurie Price
results.creator_credit: Laurie Price, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Laurie Price is one of the remaining third of those Australians who served in Korea. He provides sharp detail of the work he performed there on the airfields, the distractions and tensions, even between allies. While the war is long over, it continues to affect Price even today.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Laurie Price, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI

results.title: Shaun Gladwell: Stereo Sequences interviews
results.creator_credit: David Withers, Jason White, Csilla Csongvay and ACMI
results.brief_description: ‘Shaun Gladwell: Stereo Sequences’ is the first in the ‘New Horizons’ series of ACMI commissions. Gladwell uses filmic devices such as slow-motion and long pans to capture both tightly choreographed and improvised performances by breakdancers, skateboarders and BMX bike riders in a combination of rural and city settings. The resulting works, which he describes as “performative landscapes” are both rhythmic and poetic - distorting speed, gravity, space and time; exploring visual and spatial paradoxes. He discusses his art practice and his collaboration with other performers and artists for this exhibition. Other interviews include; Sarah Tutton (ACMI curator), Josh Raymond (Gladwell producer) Vivienne Wong (Australian Ballet) and Lamaroc (street dancer).

results.title: Jeff Lindsay in conversation with Sue Turnbull: Dark Tales, Serial Archetypes [web excerpt]
results.creator_credit: David Meagher, Csilla Csongvay and ACMI
results.brief_description:
Jeff Lindsay, author and creator of our favourite serial killer ‘Dexter’, is joined in conversation with Professor Sue Turnbull, as they explore the renaissance of macabre fairytales in popular culture.

Jeff Lindsay and Sue Turnbull touch on many of the themes covered in the ‘Fairytales Re-imagined’ symposium, providing a fascinatingly insightful discussion centred around the development of fairy tale motifs in popular culture. In this web excerpt, Lindsay focuses on cannibalism, the theme of his most recent installment ‘Dexter is delicious’. He explores it’s origins in fairy tales and the proliferation of cannibalism through online forums.
